data.Name: Rain
data.Description: Most commonly observed, drops larger than drizzle (0.02 inch / 0.5 mm or more) are considered rain. However, smaller drops are also considered raindrops if, in contrast to drizzle, they are widely separated.

data.Name: Drizzle
data.Description: Fairly uniform precipitation composed exclusively of fine drops very close together. Drizzle appears to float while following air currents, but unlike fog droplets, it falls to the ground. Quite often fog and drizzle occur together.

data.Name: Ice Pellets (Sleet)
data.Description: Precipitation of transparent or translucent pellets of ice, which are round or irregular hard grains of ice consisting of frozen raindrops, or largely melted then refrozen snowflakes.  Also known as sleet.

data.Name: Hail
data.Description: Precipitation in the form of small balls or other pieces of ice falling separately or frozen together in irregular lumps. Associated with thunderstorms, individual hail stones are ¼ inch (5 mm) or greater in diameter. Hail sizes of 1 inch (2.5 cm) or more are indicative of severe thunderstorms.

data.Name: Snow
data.Description: Precipitation of snow crystals that are mostly branched and in the form of six-pointed stars.

data.Name: Ice Crystals
data.Description: Generally occurring in very cold regions, they are falling crystals of ice in the form of needles, columns, or plates. Also called 'diamond dust', ice crystals appear like fog with individual water particles forming directly as ice. The shape of the individual ice crystals causes the 'light pillar' optical effect above the light source.

data.Name: Mist
data.Description: Visible minute water particles suspended in the atmosphere that reduce visibility to fewer than 7 miles (11 km) but more than or equal to 5/8thmile (1 km). There is often not much difference in the appearance of 'haze' and 'mist'. When the difference between the air temperature and dewpoint is 3°F (1.7°C) or less then the obscuration is usually called 'mist'.

data.Name: Fog
data.Description: Visible minute water particles (droplets) at the Earth's surface that reduce horizontal visibility to less than 5/8th mile (1 km). Unlike drizzle, fog does not fall to the ground but remains suspended.

data.Name: Haze
data.Description: A suspension in the air of extremely small, dry particles that are invisible to the naked eye and sufficiently numerous to give the air an opalescent appearance. That is the scientific way of saying haze is air pollution. There is often not much difference in the appearance of 'haze' and 'mist'. When the difference between the air temperature and dew point is greater than 3°F (1.7°C) the obscuration is usually called 'haze'.

data.Name: Sand Storm
data.Description: Particles of sand carried aloft by a strong wind. The sand particles are mostly confined to the lowest ten feet, and rarely rise more than fifty feet above the ground.

data.Name: Dust Storm
data.Description: A severe weather condition characterized by strong winds and dust-filled air over an extensive area.

data.Name: No Precipitation
data.Description: No product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapor that falls under gravitational pull from clouds.

data.Name: Sunny
data.Description: When there are no opaque (not transparent) clouds.

data.Name: Cloudy
data.Description: When the predominant/average sky condition is covered completely by opaque (not transparent) clouds. In other words, 8 octants of the sky is covered by opaque clouds.
